author: wsjcom
title: Despite Demographics, 3% Growth Is Possible
text:
To support his rebottling of secular stagnation, Jason Furman says: “The theory that today’s high price/earnings ratios are justified—meaning it simply has become more expensive to buy a given return—implies lower earnings going forward.” It implies exactly the opposite (“As Boomers Go Gray, Even 2% Growth Will Be Hard to Sustain,” op-ed, Feb. 15).
In the real world, investors are not buying “a given return.” They are buying an expected return. They will settle for a low current return—a high price/earnings ratio—if they expect...
